columns.text: In this problem, we will use the definition of an actuarially fair price to understand the maximum amount a company should be willing to pay to avoid loss of profit in the insurance scenario.

**a.** An actuarially fair price is a price wherein the premium is expected to be equal to the claims. This means that the policy is priced exactly equal to the expected losses.

 In solving for the actuarially fair premium, we need to consider the probability of loss as well as the discount rate. To solve for the actuarially fair insurance premium, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Insurance Premium}&=\dfrac{\text{Value} \times \text{Probability of loss}}{1+\text{Discount rate}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the given to the formula, we will get:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Insurance Premium}&=\dfrac{\$245,000,000 \times 0.0125}{1+0.04}\\
&=\dfrac{\$3,062,500}{1.04}\\
&=\$2,944,711.54
\end{aligned}$$

The fair insurance premium is $\$2,944,711.54$

**b.** We will use the same formula to first solve for the modified insurance premium using $0.9$ percent as the probability of loss

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Insurance Premium}&=\dfrac{\$245,000,000 \times 0.009}{1+0.04}\\
&=\dfrac{\$2,205,000}{1.04}\\
&=\$2,120,192.31
\end{aligned}$$

The new premium will be $\$2,120,192.31$

To solve for the amount that the company is willing to pay, we can simply subtract the value of the modified premium from the value in **a.** which is the actuarially fair price of the premium.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Payment for Modifications}&=\$2,944,711.54 - \$2,120,192.31\\
&=\$824,519.23
\end{aligned}$$

The maximum amount that the company is willing to pay for the modifications is $\$824,519.23$
